article: After forty-three years I have forgotten the name of the old lady, who was a _ on the newspaper route in my hometown when I was a twelve-year-old boy. Yet it remains in my memory that she taught me a lesson in _ that I shall never forget. On a winter afternoon, my fellows and I were throwing stones onto the slanted roof of the old lady's house to observe how the stones _ off the roof's edge and shot out like missiles. I found a _ smooth rock and threw it out, but it _ straight not for the roof but for a small window of the old lady's house. _ the sound of broken glass, we knew we were in trouble. We ran faster than any of our _ flew off her roof. I was so _ about getting caught that first night _ I was not concerned about the old lady with the broken window in winter. _ , a few days later I started to feel guilty for her misfortune. She _ greeted me with a smile when I gave her the newspaper, but I was no longer able to act _ I made up my mind that I would save my newspaper delivery money, and in three weeks I had seven dollars. I put the money in an envelop with a _ explaining that I was sorry for breaking her window and hope that the seven dollars would _ the cost for repairing it. I waited until it was _ to avoid being seen, and put the letter I didn't _ into her yard. To my relief, I could have the _ of, once again, looking straight into the old lady's kind eyes. The next day, I handed the old lady her newspaper. She thanked me and gave me a bag of cookies she had made herself. _ eating cookies, I felt an envelope and pulled it out of the bag. After opening it, I was shocked. Inside were the seven dollars and a short note _ , "I'm proud of you."
